content:
Despite his betrayal and ultimate defeat, Grimgold's legend lived on amongst the dwarves. Some among their kind saw him as a hero, a brave and daring warrior who had fought against impossible odds to gain wealth and power.

These dwarves began to worship Grimgold as a god, and they formed a cult around his legend. They saw themselves as the chosen followers of Grimgold, and they believed that they were destined to reclaim the power and influence that they had lost during the war with the dark faeries.

The cult of Grimgold grew in power and influence, and soon it had attracted many dwarves who were dissatisfied with their current way of life. These dwarves saw the cult as a way to gain power and wealth, and they were willing to do whatever it took to achieve their goals.

But not all of the dwarves were happy with the rise of the cult of Grimgold. Many saw it as a dangerous and foolish deviation from the traditional dwarven way of life, and they vowed to stop it from gaining any more power.

As a result, a civil war broke out amongst the dwarves, with the followers of Grimgold on one side and those who opposed them on the other. The war raged on for many years, causing great destruction and suffering amongst the dwarves.

In the end, the anti-Grimgold dwarves were able to defeat their foes and restore peace to their kingdom. But the memory of the cult of Grimgold and the civil war it had caused would never be forgotten, and the dwarves would always be wary of those who sought to lead them astray.
